title: Generation of Modern Satellite Data from Galileo Sunspot Drawings in 1612 by Deep Learning

task: Generation of synthetic SDO/HMI magnetograms and SDO/AIA EUV images from historical sunspot drawings
abstract: The paper presents a deep learning-based approach to generate modern satellite-like solar magnetograms and EUV images from historical sunspot drawings by Galileo (1612). The model uses a pix2pix architecture (a type of conditional GAN) trained on paired data of Mount Wilson Observatory sunspot drawings and corresponding SDO/HMI magnetograms and SDO/AIA EUV images. The generated images are evaluated for their consistency with real satellite data, particularly in terms of bipolar magnetic structures and unsigned magnetic flux. The study demonstrates the potential to reconstruct historical solar activity data for long-term solar cycle studies.

title: Visual Explanation of a Deep Learning Solar Flare Forecast Model and Its Relationship to Physical Parameters
author: (Yi et al.) et al.
data: ['Solar full-disk line-of-sight magnetograms from SOHO/MDI and SDO/HMI', 'SHARP parameters from HMI data', 'GOES X-ray flare data']
task: Solar flare prediction
abstract: The study presents a visual explanation of a deep learning solar flare forecast model and its relationship to physical parameters of solar active regions (ARs). The model, based on a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), predicts the daily occurrence of C-, M-, and X-class flares using full-disk magnetograms and SHARP parameters. The model is interpreted using guided backpropagation and Grad-CAM, which highlight the importance of polarity inversion lines (PILs) and specific ARs in flare prediction. The model achieves a True Skill Statistics (TSS) score of 0.65 and shows that ARs with high Grad-CAM values produce more flares. Nine SHARP parameters are found to be well correlated with Grad-CAM values.

abstract: The study presents an improved deep-learning model, Pix2PixCC, to generate more realistic solar farside magnetograms using data from the Solar Terrestrial Relations Observatory (STEREO) and the Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO). The model incorporates correlation coefficients (CCs) in its objective functions and uses a combination of farside STEREO EUV images and frontside SDO data pairs for training. The generated magnetograms show better consistency with real magnetograms compared to previous models, with averaged pixel-to-pixel CCs for full disk, active regions, and quiet regions being 0.88, 0.91, and 0.70, respectively. The AI-generated magnetograms are publicly available at the Korean Data Center for SDO.

abstract: The study presents a deep learning method (pix2pixHD) based on conditional Generative Adversarial Networks (cGAN) to generate He I 1083 nm images from SDO/AIA images. abstract: The study addresses the challenge of determining differential emission measures (DEMs) using limited EUV data from Solar Orbiter/EUI/FSI, which only observes two channels (174 and 304 Å). title: Fast Reconstruction of 3D Density Distribution around the Sun Based on the MAS by Deep Learning
author: Rahman et al.
data: ['MAS thermodynamic model data (2010 June to 2022 April, CR 2097 to CR 2256)', 'SOHO/LASCO C3 coronagraph data']
task: 3D coronal electron density distribution reconstruction
abstract: This study presents the first attempt to generate a three-dimensional (3D) coronal electron density distribution using the pix2pixHD deep learning model, significantly reducing computation time compared to traditional magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulations. The research uses photospheric solar magnetic fields as input and electron density distributions from the MHD Algorithm outside a Sphere (MAS) model as output. The AI-generated 3D electron densities are consistent with MAS simulations, achieving an average correlation coefficient of 0.97. The computation time for testing data sets is approximately 45.2 seconds using an NVIDIA TITAN XP GPU, which is much faster than the typical MAS simulation time. The AI-generated coronagraphic images are similar to the Solar Heliospheric Observatory (SOHO)/Large Angle and Spectroscopic Coronagraph (LASCO) C3 data, particularly during the solar minimum period. The AI-generated coronal density distribution can be used for space weather models on a near-real-time basis.

abstract: The paper introduces a deep learning-based approach to reconstruct solar coronal parameters (density, magnetic field, radial velocity, and temperature) in near-real-time using the Pix2PixCC model. The study leverages synoptic maps of the photospheric magnetic field as input and MAS (Magnetohydrodynamic Algorithm outside a Sphere) simulation results as output. A total of 152 deep learning models were trained and evaluated, covering 169 Carrington rotations from 2010 to 2023. The models successfully reconstructed the 3D distributions of coronal parameters from 1 to 30 solar radii with an average correlation coefficient of 0.98. The AI-generated data showed consistency with MAS simulation data during both solar active and quiet periods. The deep learning models significantly reduced computation time, taking only about 16 seconds per parameter on an NVIDIA Titan XP GPU. This approach can potentially be used for near-real-time forecasting of heliospheric propagation of solar eruptions.

abstract: The study addresses the question of which combination of channels can best translate other channels in ultraviolet (UV) and extreme UV (EUV) observations. It compares image translations among the nine channels of the Atmospheric Imaging Assembly (AIA) on board the Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO) using a deep learning (DL) model based on conditional generative adversarial networks (cGANs). The authors developed 170 DL models: 72 models for single-channel input, 56 models for double-channel input, and 42 models for triple-channel input. The performance of these models was evaluated using pixel-to-pixel correlation coefficients (CCs) within the solar disk. task: Prediction of the next solar rotation synoptic maps
abstract: The study introduces an AI-based solar surface flux transport (SFT) model to predict synoptic maps for the next solar rotation (27.2753 days) using deep learning. The model uses the latest synoptic maps and their sine-latitude grid data as inputs and is trained on data from SDO/HMI, SOHO/MDI, and NSO/GONG synoptic maps spanning 1996 to 2023. The AI model, based on the Pix2PixCC architecture, is compared with the persistent model and the conventional SFT model, showing improved performance in generating magnetic features and capturing solar dynamics such as differential rotation and meridional flow. The model achieves an average pixel-to-pixel correlation coefficient of 0.71, outperforming the conventional SFT model (0.65-0.68) and the persistent model (0.56).
